statement.p: Ida is conducting market research on the cost of auto insurance. Ida has determined that the average annual cost of auto insurance is 1339, and that the distribution of costs is normally distributed with a standard deviation of 92.
a. Find the probability that a single randomly selected consumer spends less than 1485 on auto insurance.
b. The cost of the middle 60 of auto insurance policies falls between (round to the nearest dollar):
c. The most expensive 19 of auto insurance policies cost at least how much annually?

solution.p: Define the normal distribution in Desmos: \displaystyle{N}=\text{normaldist}{\left({1339},{92}\right)}.

b. For the middle 60 of the data, need the remaining 40 of the data split between the left and right tails of the distribution. So the lower bound of the range has \displaystyle{0.2} of the area to the left and the upper bound of the range has \displaystyle{0.2} of the area to the right, which means \displaystyle{0.8} to the left. Therefore:
c. For the most expensive 19 of the distribution, need \displaystyle{0.19} of the area to the right of the data value, so need \displaystyle{1}-{0.0}{.19}={0.81} to the left. Therefore:
